title: 110_hr1525
content: The Act titled "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2007" imposes penalties for unauthorized computer activities. The "Internet Spyware (I-SPY) Prevention Act of 2007" adds a new section to Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, prohibiting illicit indirect use of protected computers. It states that unauthorized access or exceeding authorized access to a protected computer to use a program or code for another federal criminal offense can result in fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. Additionally, obtaining or transmitting personal information with intent to defraud or injure is also prohibited. The section prohibits unauthorized access to a protected computer for fraudulent purposes, imposing fines or imprisonment up to 2 years. Civil actions under state law based on this violation are restricted. The terms 'protected computer' and 'exceeds authorized access' are defined, and 'personal information' refers to specific data. The term 'personal information' includes a first and last name, address, email, phone number, SSN, driver's license, passport number, credit card or bank account details, and associated passwords. This section does not restrict authorized investigative or intelligence activities by law enforcement agencies. The text introduces a new item in the table of sections related to chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code, regarding the subdivision of a State or intelligence agency. SEC. 3. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2008 through 2011, $10,000,000 allocated to the Attorney General for prosecuting spyware, phishing, and pharming. SEC. 4. Findings and sense of Congress on enforcing cybercrimes. Congress finds that software and electronic communications are increasingly used by criminals to invade computers without authorization, particularly through spyware and phishing scams. These schemes aim to obtain personal information for theft, causing devastating damage and undermining confidence in using the Internet. Continued development of technologies is crucial in combating spyware. Response to consumer demand is crucial in the fight against spyware. Congress urges the Department of Justice to vigorously prosecute those using spyware for crimes, phishing, and pharming scams. The House of Representatives passed the bill on May 22, 2007.
